Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: A STEM toolkit enabling global air quality experiments
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase II project seeks to develop an internet-of-things (IoT) data collection and analysis platform for collaborative STEM and big data research and education, that enables collaborative, geographically dispersed collection of data from internet enabled scientific instruments. STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math) jobs are on the rise: the U.S. Department of Commerce predicts that occupations in these sectors will grow by 8.9 % from 2014 to 2024. Yet the U.S. currently faces a critical shortage of workers and students who are proficient in math and science subjects. In part, this shortage is due to a lack of interest in STEM-related fields by minorities and women. Engaging, relevant and hands on experiences are needed to encourage interest amongst these populations. This project fulfills the requests of the federal government and leading-edge STEM educators that both secondary and post-secondary institutions teach science in a way that engages students with real-world problems. The expectation is that this project will make big data accessible, while providing rewarding and appealing hands-on learning opportunities that will increase data literacy; increase scientific collaboration in education across geographic and interdisciplinary lines; and increase scientific literacy and interest across demographics, thus increasing the likelihood that students will continue to pursue scientific careers.

The proposed technology will be the first collaborative educational IoT STEM platform to be developed, and is innovative in the field of Educational Technology, which has yet to adopt web-connected sensors that generate big data on a global scale. At present, there is no mechanism for schools to collect and share real data between classrooms and schools in an organized way. The proposed innovation allows users to communicate via a global network and is capable of being paired with an unlimited variety of scientific instruments and data sources, to support versatile, engaging, coordinated, multi-school experiments and data sharing. Data science now impacts virtually every profession in some way, and the platform will uniquely expose students to big data analytics in an engaging and relevant way. In Phase 1, feasibility of approach was firmly established. Phase II objectives will be to expand the educational platform developed in Phase I to optimize national/global impact and support applicability to big data research as well as a range of sensors. Goals include to expand tools to view and analyze data, refine and expand curriculum, develop an Application Programming Interface and create software tools to manipulate and share data/curriculum. The platform's ability to promote greater learning will also be evaluated.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Summary:

Educational technology has struggled to generate web connections that can accumulate big data that is available for students on a global scale, due to issues with data collection and user technology problems. Wicked Device is working to address this through the development of a data collection and analysis platform to devise user-friendly education software. The platform has developed an interactive education tool called the Air Quality Egg, an environmental sensor that students can use to gather real-time environmental data, and share it with other networks of students through internet-connected devices. This technology will help promote STEM appreciation, improve big data analytics, and provide students with opportunities to engage in scientific data collection and analyses.

In Phase II, objectives were: 1) to develop tools that can view and analyze data, 2) to refine and expand educational curriculum, 3) to develop Application Programming Interface (API) to assist programmers in creating software to share data, 4) to evaluate the ability of the platform to promote and improve positive attitudes towards science in education settings.

Development of tools that can view and analyze data: During this aim, we focused on improving our offline tools and online cloud services which we have achieved through providing updated versions of iPhone and Android applications and updated web applications. Some of the notable improvements to our product include integration through Amazon Alexa, updated GPS tracking software and improving our World Map functionality. We have also update storage solutions to support high volumes of data, and have integrate with Google Classroom to improve user experiences and data sharing.

Refining and expanding curriculum: Through interactions with teachers, we achieved the objective of this aim by refining established curriculum and providing additional Environmental Science content that is in compliance with Next Generation Science Standards. Teachers can also take advantage of support tools to provide insights and/or needs for big data education, all of which can help contribute to future updates and applications for Wicked Device data science initiatives.

Development of an Application Programming Interface (API): We successfully developed an API that could be integrated with Air Quality Egg. Air Quality Egg has since been taken on by three resellers for distribution. The devices have also been requested on both a national and international scale. Currently, there are over 1500 “labs” logged in our system. In particular the City of Vancouver and Health Canada, which is part of the Canadian government, have requested the use of Air Quality Egg.

Evaluation of the platform’s functionality: The implementation of our system in educational settings was reviewed Rockman, an external organization that assesses educational programs. Based on their findings, Air Quality Egg was found to increase student curiosity for designing experiments and collecting data. While Air Quality Egg was shown to inspire teachers, over time, engagement was found to wane, prompting the implementation of a newsletter and marketing personnel to address this concern. It was also observed that teachers were limited to the curriculum available by the product. This may be due in part to teacher’s lack of permission from educational agencies to create original curriculum. This has influenced current work to expand curriculum for teachers. We are also working on ways to use information from students regarding how the program has influenced their understanding, engagement, and attitudes towards science after utilizing this software.

The successful completion of Phase II establishes Wicked Device’s data collection and analysis software platform as a means of promoting and enhancing environmental science education. The software, namely Air Quality Egg, will address the need for more experience-based learning and handling of large data sets that is lacking in K-12 classrooms. The ability to collaborate with other teachers and students both on regional and global scales will encourage students to become more involved in various aspects of scientific research and work in line with big data sets that are becoming more commonplace. This initiative will promote scientific teaching methods devised by STEM educators in which students are more engaged with real world problems. Furthermore, these teaching strategies are designed to foster creativity, with the hope of motivating more students to engage in further STEM education and/or employment.
